results.title: Summer scene
results.brief_description: Shows tourist attractions of Western Australia’s South West region in spring and summer. Includes wildflowers, spectacular Karri forests near Pemberton and the Pemberton swimming pool, trout fishing, and Yallingup’s caves and rocky coastal beaches.

results.title: Run nickel run: the making of a movie
results.creator_credit: Syd Donovan and TVW Channel Seven
results.brief_description: Documents the making of the feature film “Nickel Queen”. This Australian production directed by John McCallum and starring Googie Withers told the story of the widowed owner of the Mirribilli pub’s sudden turn of fortune during the mining boom in Western Australia. Includes a scene with John Laws as a hippie.

results.title: Pictures and words
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “BBC Television training film”.
Deals with the art and techniques of writing film commentaries. Illustrates the best way of making shot lists, timing the words with the pictures, and letting the pictures speak for themselves. Shows the pitfalls of various techniques, how the same pictures can tell a different story with a different commentary and what a skilful writer can do. Ends in the dubbing theatre with commentary, music and effects being recorded to the pictures.

results.title: People make papers
results.brief_description: An outstanding film conveying impressions of one day in “The Age” newspaper office in Melbourne. This early film by noted Australian director Fred Schepisi, uses dramatic photography and natural sound to capture the atmosphere of the office, and records all the phases in the production of the paper: the collection of news stories, the lay-out, the printing and the eventual distribution. The camera work is by Peter Purvis.

results.title: Film editing: interpretation and evaluation
results.brief_description: Contrasts the work of three Hollywood editors. Shows that the manner in which the film is sequenced, determines the dramatic effect. Firstly we see the film exactly as shot for a dramatic sequence, showing all scenes from various angles. Following these are three editing interpretations of the sequence by different editors. Demonstrates how, in assembling the shots, by omitting and shortening others and by different juxtaposition, the editor may control the dramatic construction. Looks at how a scene from the television series “Gunsmoke” is interpreted by different editing.

results.title: Evictions
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Richard Lowenstein
results.brief_description: Documentary/drama on police-enforced evictions in Melbourne during the 1930’s depression and the tactics the organised unemployed used at the time to combat the situation. Based on the memories of Noel Counihan and Tom Hills and adapted from the book ‘Weevils in the flour’ by Wendy Lowenstein, the film combines interviews with period reconstruction. Erwin Rado Award for Best Australian Short Fiction, Melbourne Film Festival, 1980.

results.title: Everything under the sun [Italian version]
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Otton, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Don Murray
results.brief_description: Who are the Australians? The film shows them at work, at home and at play. It depicts the sophistication of the cities and the sparseness of the outback. It reveals that already there are traditions and national pride. A study of Australia and Australians with all the variety and colour of the modern Australian scene. Note: A short version, intended mainly for overseas viewers, of “After Cook”. In English and Italian.

results.title: Ever since Giza
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Ted Davis
results.brief_description: This film tells of the history of barley. A grain of antiquity - seeds were placed in the ancient pyramids of Giza. The experimental work done by Victorian and South Australian agencies to improve the barley crop through the development of more suitable varieties for areas of different climate, standard-isation of seed and better farming techniques is shown. This film was included in the San Francisco Film Festival 1964.

results.title: Princess of the Blood robes costume
results.credit_line:
The Last Emperor, Italy / France, 1987
Designed by James Acheson
Silk screened rayon fabric
results.brief_description: This costume from The Last Emperor enlivens the Imperial court with rich reds that bring grandeur to the screen, a sense that’s reinforced by 9,500 extras who appear to be draped in delicately embroidered silk thanks to screen-printed rayon.
results.description:
From seller: A Princess of the Blood gown and overrobe from the 1987 multi Oscar-winning historical drama The Last Emperor. These women can be seen on several occasions throughout the movie, when PuYi chooses his secondary consort, and at PuYi’s wedding to the Empress. This stunning and elaborate costume consists of a full-length gown of printed red rayon satin, overprinted with dragon robe motif, similarly printed sleeveless overrobe. Also included is a black satin headband with gold filigree buttons (some have been lost over the years) and a string of glass beads and polished stones that hang down the chest, and a cream quilted cotton under robe.
It comes from the private collection of renowned producer Jeremy Thomas (who single handedly raised the $25million budget for the movie) and was archived after filming completed until only recently, when the Prop Store was proud to assist in sorting and cataloguing the incredible inventory under the guidance and in collaboration with Oscar-winning Costume Designer, Jim Acheson.
description_for_label: Colour had arrived in cinema when The Last Emperor (1987) was released but its use in costume and cinematography was Oscar-winning. The film follows Pu Yi’s transition from the last emperor of China to ordinary citizen and colour is fundamental to his journey. Deep crimson and orange hues capture both the majesty and innocence of his childhood in the Forbidden City, while grey saturates moments in jail later in life. This costume by James Acheson enlivens the Imperial court with rich reds that bring grandeur to the screen, further reinforced by 9,500 extras that appear to be draped in delicately embroidered silk thanks to screen-printed rayon.
results.credit_line_for_label:
The Last Emperor, Italy / France, 1987
Designed by James Acheson
Silk screened rayon fabric
